title-group.article-title: Comparisons of trapezoid tearing behaviors of uncoated and coated woven fabrics from experimental and finite element analysis

article-meta.aff: College of Textiles, Key Laboratory of High-Performance Fibers & Products, Ministry of Education, Donghua University, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Bohong Gu, College of Textiles, Key Laboratory of High-Performance Fibers & Products, Ministry of Education, Donghua University, Shanghai 201620, China. Email: gubh@dhu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article reports the trapezoid tearing behaviors of uncoated and coated woven fabrics in experimental and finite element analyses approaches. In experimental, trapezoid tearing behaviors of uncoated and coated woven fabrics were tested to obtain tearing load–displacement curves and tearing failure developments. The tearing strength and damage morphologies of the two kinds of fabrics were compared to find the tearing damage differences between uncoated and coated woven fabrics during the trapezoid tearing process. In finite element analysis, microstructure geometrical models of both the uncoated and coated woven fabrics were constructed to calculate the stress distribution and tearing failure propagation. There are good agreements between the finite element analysis results and those in experimental. Moreover, the influence of the coating on the trapezoid tearing properties was discussed. The tearing failure differences of the uncoated woven fabric and the base fabric in the coated woven fabric was also compared for finding the tearing failure mechanisms of the coated fabric. Such an investigation can be extended to the design of the coated woven fabric with high tearing strength.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Coated woven fabrics have a wide range of applications in civil engineering, such as geotextiles and membranes. The coated woven fabrics will be inevitably cut, punctured or stabbed by sharp objects and edges in the applications. Under sufficient long-distance or long-time tension, the local damage provides a starting point for a promptly propagating tear that leads to a catastrophic failure for textile structures. As a result, tearing damage is one of main failure types for coated woven fabric during its serving life. Investigations on the tearing mechanism of uncoated and coated woven fabrics will provide significant guidance for the fabric design and industrial applications.

There have been many literatures focusing on the tearing behaviors of woven fabrics since 1945. Krook and Fox (1945) made the pioneering attempt to explain the role of yarn properties and fabric structure in determining fabric tear strength. They observed the del-shaped opening and concluded the rule of yarns movement during a single tongue-tearing process. Hager et al. (1947) presented an analytical interpretation on the factors involved in the trapezoid-tear test. The derived equation related tear strength to specific structure and mechanical parameters of woven fabric. Based on the observations on woven fabrics under tongue tear shown by Krook and Fox (1945) and Teixeira et al. (1955) examined the relationship between variable fabric factors and tongue tear properties in a theoretical analysis approach which is beneficial for further research and applications. Turl (1956) tested sixteen fabrics in single tongue and trapezoid methods which were performed on both pendulum (Scott) and inertialess (Instron) testing machines. Comparison results showed that tearing strengths obtained from two testing methods differed dramatically and single tongue tearing is much more satisfactory compared with trapezoid method. Steele and Gruntfest (1957) proposed a general equation to relate trapezoid tearing strength to mechanical properties of constituent yarns and geometrical size of tested sample. This formula is particularly suitable to predict the tearing strength for dense texture woven fabrics. Taylor (1959) discussed the tensile strength and tearing strength of cotton cloths. The derived relation showed that tearing strength mainly depended on the spacing and strength of the yarns being torn and the force required to make them slip over the crossing threads. Hamkins and Backer (1980) utilized the commercial reprography to record local displacements and strains during and after the tear test. This simple inexpensive method made up excessive hypotheses on extensions or slippages of yarns in earlier models. Skelton (1980) proposed a theoretical analysis based on Taylor’s researching work (Taylor, 1959) and discussed two types of tearing behaviors of woven fabrics corresponding to two distinct failure configurations. Popescu et al. (1985) studied the effect of technological processes on the mechanical behaviors of wool yarns and woven fabrics. Experimental results revealed that scouring and dyeing had severe negative influences on the tearing strength of woven fabrics. Lloyd (1989a, 1989b) developed a simple theory to give semi-quantitative explanations of factors affecting the strength required to tear fastenings through woven fabrics. The cases of tearing along warp or weft directions and the bias direction were both taken into account. Chu et al. (1991) adopted four tearing test methods to measure the tear strength of 15 coated fabrics and analyzed the relationship between the trapezoid tear strength and fabric structural parameters for both uncoated and coated fabrics. Petrulis (1992) presented mathematical models to predict the tearing strength and tearing propagation strength of woven polyester fabrics. Popova and Iliev (1993) studied the tearing strength of geomembrane composites on textile base using experimental and numerical methods. The theoretical results provided the possibility of finding a generalized mechanical index for a mathematical description of the tearing processes. Eichert (1994) discussed the residual tensile and tear strength of coated industrial fabrics under long-term natural weather conditions. Scelzo et al. (1994a, 1994b) analyzed the contributions of structural parameters (e.g. tearing rate, yarn type and weave structure) to the tear resistance for cotton woven fabrics and established a predictive model based on a mechanical spring analogy to forecast tearing response of woven fabrics. Godfrey and Rossettos (1999a, 1999b) and Godfrey et al. (2004) developed a simple micromechanical model to predict the onset of tearing propagation at slits in biaxially stressed uncoated and coated plain weave fabrics. The results of experiments which were carried out on a variety of nylon and polyester uncoated and coated fabrics showed good agreement with the large-slit analysis model. Primentas (2001) put forward a ‘COMPUTE’ device which was used for investigating the combined puncture and tear propagation of fabrics. It can be concluded that the longer tear length occurred when the weight of the puncture tool carriage became heavier and the impact angle was small. Witkowska and Frydrych (2004, 2008a, 2008b) gave a comparison of tearing strength between different static tearing methods and emphatically introduced the tearing stages for wing-shaped test specimens using computer image analysis technique. Zhong et al. (2004) utilized the Ising model combined with the Monte Carlo method to simulate the tongue tearing failure for coated woven fabric, where the effect of the interface effect is taken into account. The theoretical model was proved to be effective for predicting the mechanical characteristics of heterogeneous materials. Rossettos and Godfrey (2005) carried out a micromechanical model to study the tearing propagation of slit-damaged braided fabric air-beam structure. This research achievement will contribute to the prediction of damage growth and the ability to compare different fabric materials for their damage tolerance. Mukhopadhyay et al. (2006) reported an experimental investigation on the tearing and tensile strength of military khaki fabrics from grey to finished process (such as bleaching and dyeing). The results showed that tensile strength is relatively less sensitive while tearing strength dropped significantly during the grey to finished process. Dhamija and Chopra (2007) investigated the effect of spinning method and loom parameters on the tearing strength while Krasteva (2007) compared five different fabrics using four tearing methods and analyzed possible reasons. Luo et al. (2008) and Luo and Hu (2009) studied the tensile and tearing behaviors of PVC coated bi-axial warp knitted fabric. It was found that the mechanical performance decreased with increase of the initial crack length and the crack propagation is always progressively along the weft direction of the fabric under multi-axial tensile condition. Maekawa et al. (2008) carried out biaxial tensile test and pressurized cylinder test to simulate the biaxial stress field on an airship envelope materials. Empirical formulas for the tear propagation were evaluated to be applicable to the Zylon envelope material. Kadem and Ogulata (2009) employed statistical analyses methods using SPSS package to analyze and predict tear strength of cotton woven fabrics with different structural parameters. The comparison between experimental and theoretical results demonstrated good agreement. Pamuk and Çeken (2009) tested the breaking strength and tearing strength of fabrics used for automobile seat covers. This study provided the possibility of applying statistical theory to the modeling and analysis of data on technical textiles performance. Chen et al. (2010) introduced a lattice-based finite element method to analyze tear performance of coated fabric treating the perpendicular yarns as a two-spring system. The result was beneficial for designing explosion-proof structure. Hussain et al. (2010) developed a validated regression model with predictor variables to forecast the crease recovery and tear strength properties of cotton fabric. Bai et al. (2011) evaluated the notch sensitivity and tear resistance of the Kevlar-PWF-reinforced TPU film applied in high altitude balloon. Static tension and tear test results revealed that the tensile resistance and tear resistance had significant notch sensitivity. Bilisik et al. (2011) studied tearing strength of the dry and wet states of rubbed flocked fabric and washed flocked fabric. A regression model was developed to explain the relationships between stroke number and tearing strength of the dry and wet states of rubbed flocked fabrics. Liu et al. (2011) conducted mono-axial center slit tear tests on coated fabrics. The results showed that the tearing strength and displacement decreased with the increase of inclining angle and slit lengths. Bigaud et al. (2003) concerned about the crack propagation behavior of textile structure reinforced soft composite. They investigated the influences of initial crack length, crack orientation and coating material on the tearing propagation and constructed FE model to simulate the tearing failure process.

In the abovementioned literatures, few researches were focused on the comparison of trapezoid tearing behaviors between uncoated and coated woven fabrics. Moreover, there is still lack of a valid model to accurately depict the tearing process and tearing damage evolution for the uncoated and the coated woven fabrics.

In this article, we will concentrate on comparison of the trapezoid tearing behaviors of uncoated and coated woven fabrics from experimental and FEA. In experimental, the trapezoid tearing behaviors of two kinds of woven fabrics were tested on Material Test System (MTS 810.23) based on the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D 5587-96. Tearing strength-displacement curves and tearing damage morphologies were obtained and compared between two fabrics. In FEA, the microstructure FE models of uncoated and coated woven fabrics were established in a commercial FEA package ABAQUS (version 6.10). The detailed information on the FEA model was presented. The theoretical predictions of the tearing behaviors of uncoated and coated woven fabrics were compared with experiments.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
Both the uncoated and coated woven fabrics were supplied from the Army Fuel Logistics Institute of China. The uncoated woven fabric is 2/1 twill woven fabric made up of high tenacity polyethylene terephthalate (PET) continuous filament fiber tows. The coating material is thermoplastic urethane (TPU). Specifications of the uncoated and the coated woven fabrics are given in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. Figures 1 and 2 show the surface and cross-sectional photographs of uncoated and coated woven fabrics. Figure 1.
Photographs of the uncoated woven fabric: (a) surface; (b) cross-sections of warp yarns; (c) cross-sections of weft yarns.
Figure 2.
Photographs of the coated woven fabric: (a) surface; (b) cross-section.
Table 1.
Specifications of the uncoated woven fabric.
Fabric structure Material Thickness (mm) Areal density (g/m2) Warp density (ends/5 cm) Weft density (ends/5 cm)
2/1 twill PET 2.19 920 28 19
PET: polyethylene terephthalate.
Table 2.
Specifications of the coated woven fabric.
Coating material Thickness (mm) Areal density (g/m2)
TPU 2.5 2950
TPU: thermoplastic urethane.

sec.title: Environmental conditions
sec.p: Environment for all tests was maintained at a relative humidity of 65 ± 4.0% and a temperature of 20 ± 2.0°C as ISO 139-2005 recommended.

sec.title: Tensile tests
sec.p: Tensile strength tests were operated on the uncoated and coated woven fabrics based on the ASTM D5035-06. The extension direction was along the warp direction because the tearing tests were along the weft direction. Under the weft direction tearing, the warp yarns will be under the tension loads. Effective gauge size of tested sample is 200 mm in length and 50 mm in width with 30 warp yarns (extra two warp yarns are reserved for accidental slippage of selvage warp yarns) along the loading direction. All tensile tests were carried out on MTS 810.23 at tensile speed of 100 mm/min.

In addition, the tensile properties of warp and weft yarns in 2/1 twill woven fabric were also measured based on ASTM D885-07. The mechanical parameters of the yarns were obtained and input into the FEA model for numerical calculations.

sec.title: Trapezoid tearing tests
sec.p:
The trapezoid-shaped specimen of uncoated and coated woven fabrics with an initial edge slit is shown in Figure 3(a) and (b), respectively. Figure 3(c) illustrates the geometrical dimension of tested sample which is based on the ASTM D 5587-96. The pre-existence slit on the top of the specimen is 15 mm in length. The shadow zones in the Figure 3(c) represent clamping areas in the upper and lower jaws. The trapezoid tearing tests were carried out on MTS 810.23 tester as shown in Figure 4. In Figure 4, the inclined clamping lines of trapezoid specimen rotated into parallel positions and the clamping areas of the tested sample were inserted into the jaws of MTS. Tearing tests were carried out along the weft direction. The speed of the upper jaw was set as 100 mm/min. Figure 3.
Photograph of the trapezoid tearing specimen: (a) the uncoated trapezoid tearing specimen; (b) the coated trapezoid tearing specimen; (c) geometrical dimension of the trapezoid tearing specimen.
Figure 4.
Trapezoid tearing test on Material Test System (MTS 810.23): (a) structure diagram of 2/1 twill woven fabric; (b) geometrical structure of warp and weft yarns in the FE model.
FE: finite element.

sec.title: Finite element model
sec.p: FEA modeling of the trapezoid tearing tests was carried out in commercial FEA software ABAQUS/Explicit (version 6.10).

sec.title: Geometrical model
sec.p:
Based on the models developed by Valizadeh et al. (2010), the following assumptions were made in current FEA geometrical model:
Yarns in woven fabric are considered to be homogeneous solids with ellipse cross-sections. The inside gap between fibers of yarns is ignored.
The surface of yarns is assumed to be uniform and smooth. The effects of surface roughness are considered by introducing the friction effect between yarns.
In the initial state, all warp and weft yarns are in a compact contact and no gap exists at each interweaving point.

According to cross-sectional photographs of warp and weft yarns in Figure 1, the ratio of major axis to minor axis of the ellipse section was set as 3. For numerical calculation of the major axis and minor axis of the ellipse, it’s reasonable to assume that the PET filaments are compact packed. With this assumption, the fibers fill 90.7% of the whole cross section. Most PET filament fiber tows have a density close to 1.38 g/cm3. Then the nominal density of PET yarns is 1.25 g/cm3. Therefore, the length of the minor axis of ellipse section is given by b=Tex106×ρyarn×10-3×3π=Tex11775 where b is the length of minor axis in the ellipse section (mm); Tex, the warp or weft yarn fineness (g/1000 m); ρyarn, the nomical density of the yarn (g/cm3).

In FEA modeling, the yarns were constructed as shown in Figure 5. Table 3 gives the detailed geometrical dimensions in the FE model. Figure 5.
Geometrical model of yarns in 2/1 twill woven fabric.
Table 3.
Geometrical dimension of the yarns in FEA model.
aj (mm) aw (mm) bj (mm) bw (mm) dj (mm) dw (mm)
0.831 1.035 0.277 0.345 1.79 2.63
FEA: finite element analysis.

The initial geometry of the uncoated and coated woven fabric is illustrated in Figures 6 and 7, respectively. Figures 8 and 9 illustrate the pre-existent edge slit in the FEA model of the uncoated and coated woven fabrics. The pre-existent slit cut five weft yarns in the shorter edge of the FE model. Figure 10 depicts the schematic diagram of the coated woven fabric in the FEA model. Figure 6.
FEA model of the uncoated woven fabric.
FEA: finite element analysis.
Figure 7.
FEA model of the coated woven fabric.
FEA: finite element analysis.
Figure 8.
Pre-existence slit in the FEA model of the uncoated woven fabric.
FEA: finite element analysis.
Figure 9.
Pre-existence slit in the FEA model of the coated woven fabric.
FEA: finite element analysis.
Figure 10.
Schematic diagram of the coating in the FEA model.
FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Meshing scheme
sec.p:
The uncoated woven fabric was dominantly meshed with eight-node, hexahedral reduced integration elements as shown in Figure 11. In the regions that near the clamping lines, it is consisted of six-node, tetrahedral elements due to the complexity of geometric structure. In the FE model of coated woven fabric, the mesh scheme of the base fabric was the same with that of the uncoated woven fabric. Figure 12 demonstrates the detailed mesh scheme for coated woven fabric. The quality of the mesh results is checked to prevent distorted elements from obtaining inaccurate results. In the FE model, there are 60,387 elements for the uncoated woven fabric and additional 291,353 elements for coating in the coated woven fabric. Figure 11.
Mesh scheme of the uncoated woven fabric in the FEA model.
FEA: finite element analysis.
Figure 12.
Mesh scheme of the coated woven fabric in the FEA model.
FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Material mechanical behaviors
sec.p:
In order to simplify the model, the yarns were assumed as isotropic and elastic-plastic material as the software ABAQUS supplied. Figure 13 shows a simplified stress–strain curve of elastic-plastic yarns. In Figure 13, σy is the yield stress; ɛy is the maximum elastic strain; σp is the peak stress; ɛp is the strain corresponding to peak stress; ɛf is the failure strain and ɛpl0 is the maximum plastic strain. E=σyɛy(E:Young ' s modulus) ɛpl0=ɛp-ɛy Figure 13.
Stress–strain curve of yarns.

In Figure 13, the yarn was linearly elastic under low load condition. With the load reached to the yield stress, the yarn entered into plastic deformation stage (after yield point A). When the stress of a single element reached the peak stress (point B), the damage will be occurred. The failure strain ɛf depends on characteristic length of the element. Figure 14 demonstrates the flow chart of the FE solver in ABAQUS/Explicit. Figure 14.
Flow chart of finite element solver in ABAQUS/Explicit.

sec.title: Steps
sec.p:
To simulate the trapezoid tearing process of the uncoated coated woven fabrics, two continuous steps were defined in the FE model. The first step (referring as Step-1) was designed to construct a symmetric arch-shape geometric structure. The final damage morphology of the uncoated and coated specimens at the end of Step-1 (namely, the initial state in Step-2) is shown in Figures 15 and 16, respectively. In the second step (referring as Step-2), the specimen suffered uniaxial tensile loading tearing damage and the pre-existence slit propagated along the warp direction (weft yarns failed). Figure 15.
Final status of the uncoated specimen at the end of Step-1.
Figure 16.
Final state of the coated specimen at the end of Step-1.

sec.title: Loads and boundary conditions
sec.p:
The woven fabric in the FE model is aligned with x-z plane (also be referred as 1-3 plane). There are 56 warp yarns with different lengths along the x-axis (1-direction) and 38 weft yarns with different lengths along the z-axis (3-direction) approximately. Figure 17 gives an overall view of the boundary conditions applying to the FE model. In Figure 17, the Set-2 which was comprised of all surfaces on the left sloped edge was defined as a rigid set with reference point RP-1. The similar setting was operated on Set-3 with reference point RP-2. Detailed settings and regions of five boundary conditions are listed in Table 4. U1, U2 and U3 is the 1-, 2-, 3-directional translational degrees of freedom respectively and UR1, UR2 and UR3 is the 1-, 2-, 3-directional rotational degrees of freedom, respectively. V1, V2 and V3 is the 1-, 2-, 3-directional translational velocity, respectively and VR1, VR2 and VR3 is the 1-, 2-, 3-directional rotational velocity, respectively. Figure 17.
Boundary conditions in the FEA model.
FEA: finite element analysis.
Table 4.
Boundary conditions in FEA model.
Step Boundary Name Settings Regions
Step-1 BC-1 UR2 = −0.523 radians; U1 = U2 = U3 = UR1 = UR3 = 0 RP-1
BC-2 UR2 = 0.523 radians; U1 = U2 = U3 = UR1 = UR3 = 0 RP-2
BC-3 V2 = 30 mm/s; V1 = V3 = VR1 = VR2 = VR3 = 0 Set-1
Step-2 BC-4 V3 = −0.83 mm/s; V1 = V2 = VR1 = VR2 = VR3 = 0 RP-1
BC-5 V3 = 0.83 mm/s; V1 = V2 = VR1 = VR2 = VR3 = 0 RP-2
U1, U2, U3: 1-, 2-, 3-directional translational degrees of freedom, respectively; UR1, UR2, UR3: 1-, 2-, 3-directional rotational degrees of freedom, respectively; V1, V2, V3: 1-, 2-, 3-directional translational velocity, respectively; VR1, VR2, VR3: 1-, 2-, 3-directional rotational velocity, respectively.
FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Contact algorithms
sec.p: The contact definitions in the FE model of uncoated woven fabric was ‘GENERAL CONTACT’ with frictional coefficient of 0.1 for the interaction between warp and weft yarns. As for the contact between the coating and fabric, a ‘TIE’ constraint was defined at the interface of the base fabric and coating to stitch the two meshes together. The mesh size at the interface is specially designed sharing the same node (shown in Figure 12). This will avoid undesirable mesh distortion due to the tie adjustment during tearing damage.

To develop the governing equations for contact, assume that, at some time t0, a part I of the surface of two bodies, A and B(represents warp and weft yarns respectively), comes into contact. Denote the velocities and accelerations of corresponding parts just as u·AI_,u·BI_,u··AI_,u··BI_ and u·AI+,u·BI+,u··AI+,u··BI+ just after contact.

The fully plastic contact assumption requires that corresponding points acquire the same velocity and acceleration in the direction of contact immediately after contact so that, at time t0+ (1)n·u·AI=n·u·BIn·u··AI=n·u··BI
Here n is the current normal to the interface surface I.
Writing Δu·=u·+-u·- to describe the velocity ‘jump’ at t0 at a point, we have (2)n·(u·AI-+Δu·AI)=n·(u·BI-+Δu·BI)
The component of the force per unit area between the bodies across I in the normal direction n, NI, must satisfy (3)NAI=-NBIfort≥t0NAI=NBI=0fort<t0

Since finite velocity jumps are occurring at the time of contact in infinitesimal time (compared to the time scale of the simulation), during the infinitesimal interval t0- to t0+, NI dominates all other forces in the system except for the d’Alembert forces. This simplifies the virtual work equation during t0- to t0+ to (4)∑A,B[∫Vρu···δudV]+∫INAn·δuAdS+∫INBn·δuBdS=0
Integrating from t0_ to t0+, (5)∑A,B[∫V∫t0-t0+ρu···δudV]+∫I∫t0-t0+(NAn·δuA+NBn·δuB)dS=0

But n·δuA=n·δuB at t0, and NB=-NA, so the second term in equation (5) is zero. However, the constraint (equation (5)) must be satisfied by augmenting equation (5) with a Lagrange multiplier term with H as the multiplier: ∑A,B[∫Vρu···δudV]+∫Iδ[Hn·(u·AI_+Δu·AI_-u·BI_-Δu·BI_)]ds

The first term has been integrated over t0- to t0+ to give the velocity jump term. Taking the variation in the second term and noting that n cannot rotate in the infinitesimal time interval because there is no discontinuity in displacement, we obtain (6)∑A,B[∫Vρu···δudV]+∫IHn·(δuAI-δuBI)ds+∫I(Δu·AI-Δu·BI)·nδHds =-∫I(Δu·AI_-Δu·BI_)·nδHds

This equation can be solved for the velocity jump Δu· at all nodes. The solution also provides the impulse per unit area, H: the time integral of the pressure between the surfaces over the infinitesimal time of contact. The equilibrium equation written at time t0+ and including the constraint that n·(u··AI-u··BI)=0 can then be used to obtain the initial accelerations immediately after initial contact between the warp and weft yarns.

sec.title: Output requirements
sec.p: The reaction force on the RP-1 along the 3-direction was defined as the output data. It is referred as ‘RF3’ in ABAQUS. As mentioned above, RP-1 was the reference point of the rigid set Set-2. The reaction force on RP-1 is the tearing strength in theoretical. The theoretical tearing strength will be compared with that in experimental.

sec.title: Tensile strength of yarns in 2/1 twill woven fabric
sec.p:
Figure 18 gives the tensile stress–strain curves of warp and weft yarns which were pulled out from the uncoated 2/1 twill woven fabric. From these curves, the average elastic modulus of the warp and weft yarns can be calculated. The detailed specifications and mechanical parameters are listed in Table 5. Table 6 lists the elastic-plastic parameters for warp yarn, weft yarn and coating in the FEA model. Figure 18.
Tensile stress–strain curves of: (a) warp; (b) weft yarns pulled out from uncoated woven fabric.
Table 5.
Specifications and mechanical parameters of yarns in 2/1 twill woven fabric.
Yarns Yarn fineness (tex) Cross-sectional area (m2) Modulus (GPa) Volume density (g/cm3) Poisson’s ratio
Warp 454 × 2 (2 multifilament yarns) 7.25 × 10−7 7.32 1.25 0.2
Weft 700 × 2 (2 multifilament yarns) 1.12 × 10−6 6.97
Table 6.
Elastic-plastic parameters in the FEA model.
Materials Modulus(GPa) Yield stress (MPa) Peak stress (MPa) Plastic strain (%)
Warp 7.32 850 900 0.5
Weft 6.97 820 840 0.5
Coating 0.1 20 30 100
FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Tensile strength of the uncoated and coated woven fabrics
sec.p:
The tensile strength–displacement curves of the uncoated and coated woven fabrics along warp direction are shown in Figure 19. Three tests were conducted for each test condition. It can be seen from Figure 19 that the tensile strength and displacement of uncoated woven fabric is greater than those of coated woven fabric. This is mainly due to the relative slippage between yarns was restricted by the coating resin. The yarns cannot be oriented along the direction of tension load. Figure 20 compares the damage morphologies of the uncoated and coated woven fabrics after tensile failure. The uncoated woven fabric is looser than that of the coated woven fabric after failure because of the restriction of coating resin. This is also the reason why the uncoated fabric has the higher tensile strength. Figure 19.
Tensile load–displacement curves of uncoated and coated woven fabrics.
Figure 20.
Damage morphologies of: (a) uncoated woven fabric; (b) base fabric of the coated woven fabric under tensile load.

sec.title: Trapezoid tearing strength of the uncoated and coated woven fabrics
sec.p:
Figure 21 compares the trapezoid tearing behaviors between the uncoated and coated woven fabrics. For each test, two samples were tore to obtain the average tearing behaviors. It is shown that the tearing strength of the uncoated and coated woven fabric is much the same. Under the tensile test (Figure 19), the uncoated fabrics have higher displacement and strength. But under tearing test (Figure 21), the uncoated fabrics have lower displacement at the initial stage with the same strength. The main reasons of this phenomenon are probably that the yarns in uncoated woven fabrics will be straightened easily at the initial tearing stage, while still in the crimp state at the first tearing stage in coated woven fabric. The straightened yarns will induce the lower displacement at the same tearing load compared with that in the coated woven fabric. Figure 21.
Trapezoid tearing load–displacement curves of uncoated and coated woven fabrics.

Based on Figure 21, tearing stress was partly resisted by flexible coating resin material by shear toughening mechanism as showed ductile behavior in Figure 21, then failure occurred depending upon base fabric material behavior.

The damage morphologies for the uncoated and coated woven fabrics are displayed in Figures 22 and 23, respectively. It is obvious that the tearing damage area of the uncoated woven fabric is greater than that of the coated fabric. In addition, the fracture of weft yarns in the uncoated woven fabric was irregular while the slit propagated along a straight line strictly in the coated woven fabric. Figure 22.
Damage morphology of the uncoated woven fabric.
Figure 23.
Damage morphology of the coated woven fabric.

The stability of the tearing strength is mainly due to the function of the coating resin. Although the coating resin restricts the slippage the yarns, resin itself also contributes to the tearing strength of the coated woven fabric. The two contrary effects offset each other resulting in slight difference of tearing strength between uncoated and coated woven fabrics.

sec.title: Comparison of trapezoid tearing strength between numerical and experimental
sec.p:
The simulation results from FE model of the uncoated and coated woven fabrics are compared with experimental results as illustrated in Figures 24 and 25, respectively. There are good agreements between FEA and experimental results. It also could be found that the fluctuation in the FEM curve is greater than that in experimental curve. In the FEA calculation, the yarn is simplified as a continuum. While in experimental, the filaments within the yarns will undergo the non-simultaneous breakage. This is the main reason for the great fluctuation in the theoretical tearing strength–displacement curve. Figure 24.
Comparison of load–displacement curves of the uncoated woven fabric between FEA and experimental.
FEA: finite element analysis.
Figure 25.
Comparison of load–displacement curves of the coated woven fabric between FEA and experimental.
FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Comparison of tearing failure between numerical and experimental
sec.p:
Figure 26 compares the tearing failure of the coated woven fabrics between FEA and experimental. Tearing deformation and damage at five stages were presented. It is shown that the FEA results of the coated woven fabric are similar with those in experimental. The tearing damage is mainly located in an oval-shaped area. From the initial stage to the final stage of the tearing damage, the edge slit gradually extended across the width of the sample. Figure 26.
Comparisons of tearing process of the coated woven fabric between FEA and experimental.
FEA: finite element analysis.

sec.title: Comparison of the tearing damage between base woven fabric and the uncoated woven fabric
sec.p:
The woven fabric in the coated woven fabric is called as ‘base woven fabric’. To investigate the effect of the coating resin to the tearing resistance of the coated woven fabric, the coating resin on the coated woven fabric was removed in ABAQUS/Viewer. Comparisons of the tearing failure process between the two kinds of woven fabrics at the same time step are shown in Figure 27. It can be seen in Figure 27 that there are not slippages between warp yarns and weft yarns in the base fabric. Moreover, the stress on the base woven fabric is distributed more evenly comparing with that on the uncoated woven fabric. This is mainly due to the coating resin transmits the concentrated stress to more fiber tows. Figure 27.
Comparisons of tearing damage between (a) the base fabric in the coated woven fabric and (b) the uncoated fabric during the trapezoid tearing process.

In the coated woven fabric, the tearing damage mechanisms are mainly the shear failure of the flexible coating resins and the tension failure of warp yarns when the tearing is along the weft direction. The existence of the resin restricts the shear deformation of the base woven fabric. While for the uncoated woven fabric, the tearing damage is mainly from the tension failure of the warp yarns. The shear deformation of the uncoated woven fabric will induce the jamming of the yarns at the local tearing delta zone. For both the uncoated and coated woven fabrics, the friction among the warp and weft yarns will influence the tearing damage propagation significantly. The higher the friction coefficient, the higher will be the tearing strength.

sec.title: Analysis of trapezoid tearing damage mechanisms
sec.p: Trapezoid tearing is a process of damage propagation of edge slit under uniaxial tension. On application of force to the fabric by the testing machine, weft yarns held in the jaws stretch and lose crimp. Moreover, warp yarns start slipping across weft yarns due to the tensile force applied by the jaws and frictional force between warp and weft yarns. The integrated effects form a triangular-shaped opening in which there are no warp yarns as shown in the second picture of Figure 27(b). With further stretching of jaws, warp yarns continue to slip and crowd together which increases the size of the tearing opening and forms a large number of frictional points of contact in a small area of fabric. As the number of these contact points builds up, it becomes more and more difficult for slippage to occur and the size of the tearing opening reaches the maximum. As the load builds up further, one or more weft yarns fail (the third picture in Figure 27(b)) and yarns slip by each other subsequently to form next tearing opening. These processes are continuously repeated until the failure extends over the width of tested specimen.

The trapezoid tearing mechanism immediately explains the occurrence of the maxima and minima on the tearing strength–displacement curves. As the load is applied to the specimen, weft yarns stretch and warp yarns move towards the upper and lower jaws forming a smooth growth of tearing strength. Once one or more weft yarns fail, there will be a significant drop in the tearing strength–displacement curve. Further slippage between following warp and weft yarns generate next tearing opening with increasing tearing strength. And so the cycle continues.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Tearing behaviors of uncoated and coated woven fabrics are one of the most important properties during their serving life. In this article, trapezoid tearing properties of uncoated and coated woven fabrics were investigated and compared in experimental and FEA approaches. The tearing strength and damage morphologies predicted by microstructure FE model agree well with that in experiments. From above two approaches, it can be concluded that although the coating restricts the relative slippage between warp and weft yarns, the trapezoid tearing strength of the coated woven fabric is much the same with that of uncoated sample. In addition, the stress distribution and propagation on samples calculated by FEA approach visibly demonstrate the difference of tearing failure characters between two fabrics. We hope such an investigation can help designers and manufacturers to optimum the microstructure of the uncoated and coated woven fabrics and to extend the application to flexible pipelines, geomembranes and architecture membranes.

This work is supported by Program for Innovative Research Team (in Science and Technology) in University of Henan Province (2009HASTIT027 and 2010IRTSTHN007), and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China.
